p: Chronic exposure to air pollution is also associated with pulmonary inflammation, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and lung cancer. Several studies suggest that chronic exposure to outdoor air pollution increases the prevalence and incidence of COPD [ 24]. Moreover, among individuals with COPD, air pollution is associated with increased respiratory symptoms, loss of lung function, COPD exacerbations and higher mortality [ 24]. Air pollution is also linked to lung cancer, and the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) has classified the particulate matter in outdoor air pollution as carcinogenic to humans [ 25].
